title: 104_s2061
content: The Act titled "Agricultural Trade Reform Act of 1996" defines the term "Domestic Industry, etc." The Trade Act of 1974 amends the definition of "domestic industry" to include producers of like or competitive articles or perishable agricultural products in specific geographic areas of the United States. The Trade Act of 1974 expands the definition of "domestic industry" to include producers in specific geographic areas of the United States whose production constitutes a significant portion of the total domestic production of the article. The Trade Act of 1974 broadens the definition of "domestic industry" to include producers of perishable agricultural products, citrus products, or potato products in specific geographic areas of the United States that constitute a significant portion of the domestic industry and primarily serve the local market. If there are substantial imports of similar products in the area, only that portion of the domestic industry is considered. The Trade Act of 1974 expands the definition of "domestic industry" to include producers of perishable agricultural products, citrus products, or potato products in specific geographic areas of the United States that are a significant part of the industry. The term "specific geographic area of the United States" refers to a distinct area where these products are produced, while "significant portion of the domestic industry in the United States" means an important part of the industry characterized by production in the same growing season. SEC. 3. PROVISIONAL RELIEF. Section 202(d)(1)(C) of the Trade Act of 1974 is amended to allow for provisional relief in cases where a petition alleges injury from imports of perishable agricultural, citrus, or potato products that have been monitored by the Commission for at least 90 days. Requests for relief can be made by the President, Trade Representative, or relevant committees. The Committee on Ways and Means or the Committee on Finance may provide provisional relief to prevent serious injury to the domestic industry from increased imports of perishable agricultural, citrus, or potato products. The Commission must make a determination within 21 days of the request to assess if imports are causing harm to the domestic industry. The Commission may provide provisional relief to prevent serious injury to the domestic industry producing perishable agricultural, citrus, or potato products. The determination must be made within 21 days to assess if imports are causing harm. In considering a petition or request, the Commission may waive the 90-day timeframe. The Commission may waive the 90-day monitoring requirement if there is evidence of significant increases in production or capacity in the exporting country, leading to a threat of serious injury to the domestic industry. The Commission can waive the 90-day monitoring requirement if there is evidence of increased production or capacity in the exporting country, posing a threat to the domestic industry. Amendments are made to sections of the Act to ensure consistency in import quantities. Amendments are made to the Act to include "perishable agricultural product, citrus product, or potato product" in relevant sections. The term "potato product" is defined as any potato product, including processed ones.
